title: AIMS65 Score for Upper GI Bleeding Mortality
description: Predicts in-hospital mortality in patients with acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding using 5 simple clinical variables

parameters.name: mental_status_altered
parameters.description: Altered mental status (confusion, disorientation, or altered consciousness)

ranges.interpretation: AIMS65 score 0-1: Low risk of in-hospital mortality (0.3-7.8%). Consider outpatient management or early discharge for stable patients.
AIMS65 score 2: Moderate risk of in-hospital mortality (~20%). Consider inpatient monitoring and early endoscopy.
AIMS65 score 3-5: High risk of in-hospital mortality (36-50%). Requires intensive monitoring, urgent endoscopy, and aggressive management.

references: Saltzman JR, Tabak YP, Hyett BH, Sun X, Travis AC, Johannes RS. A simple risk score accurately predicts in-hospital mortality, length of stay, and cost in acute upper GI bleeding. Gastrointest Endosc. 2011;74(6):1215-24.
Hyett BH, Abougergi MS, Charpentier JP, et al. The AIMS65 score compared with the Glasgow-Blatchford score in predicting outcomes in upper GI bleeding. Gastrointest Endosc. 2013;77(4):551-7.
Thandassery RB, Sharma M, John AK, et al. Clinical application of AIMS65 scores to predict outcomes in patients with upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Clin Endosc. 2015;48(5):380-4.

Park SW, Song YW, Tak DH, et al. The AIMS65 score is a useful predictor of mortality in patients with nonvariceal upper gastrointestinal bleeding: urgent endoscopy in patients with high AIMS65 scores. Clin Endosc. 2015;48(6):522-7.
formula: AIMS65 = A + I + M + S + 65, where each component scores 1 point if present: Albumin <3.0 g/dL, INR >1.5, Mental status altered, Systolic BP ≤90 mmHg, Age ≥65 years
notes: Each component (A, I, M, S, 65) contributes 1 point if criteria met
Score ≥2 indicates high mortality risk and need for urgent intervention
Superior to other scores in predicting in-hospital mortality
Can be calculated early (within 12 hours) without endoscopic findings
Helps guide triage decisions and resource allocation
Validated in multiple studies across different populations
